title: A Museum Shows the First YouTube Video and Page
summary: The Victoria & Albert Museum in London is displaying a special exhibit about YouTube. They rebuilt the first YouTube page from 2006 so visitors can see what it looked like back then. The museum also has the first video ever uploaded to YouTube, called Me at the Zoo, which was posted in 2005 by one of YouTube's founders. This video has been watched millions of times and helped start the trend of people making and sharing videos online. The museum wants to show how YouTube changed the internet and design. They have other digital items like WeChat and Flappy Bird too. This exhibit lets people learn about digital history in a fun way.

background_read: YouTube started in 2005 as a website for sharing videos. It became very popular because anyone could upload videos, not just big companies. Museums like the V&A collect digital things to show how technology changes our lives. This helps people understand the past and how we use the internet today.
Article_Structure: WHO: The Victoria & Albert Museum and YouTube worked together.
WHAT: They displayed a rebuilt YouTube page and the first video called Me at the Zoo.
WHERE: At the V&A museum in London.
WHY: To teach people about digital history and how YouTube started.

perspectives.description: The museum uses the exhibit to teach visitors about internet history.
